title: The Zero-Sum Suicide: An Economic Autopsy of Vermont’s Payer-Provider War
summary: The social contract of Vermont healthcare is dead. With residents paying 19.6% of their income on premiums to fund a system defined by $6,520 MRIs and adversarial oligopolies, the market has ceased to function. This analysis dissects the Fee-For-Service pathology and argues that Global Budgets are the only exit from the demographic death spiral.

children.text: The social contract of Vermont healthcare is dead. It did not die from natural causes; it was strangled by a toxic economic feedback loop known as the Fee-For-Service (FFS) model.

The current public warfare between Blue Cross Blue Shield of Vermont (BCBSVT) and the University of Vermont Medical Center (UVMMC) is not a standard contract dispute. It is a symptom of Allocative Failure. When a state’s residents pay 19.6% of their household income on insurance premiums—nearly triple the national average—to fund a system where a single MRI scan costs $6,520, the market has ceased to function as a mechanism for value and has become a mechanism for extraction.
I. The Data: The Price of Leverage

The catalyst for this open conflict is BCBSVT’s unprecedented 'VT Affordable Care' campaign, which explicitly urges patients to bypass the state’s academic medical center. The insurer, facing a $62.1 million deficit and paying out $35 million weekly in claims, has broken the omertà of the healthcare industry to reveal the raw unit prices driving these deficits.

The data reveals a market defined by extreme price dispersion, which violates the Law of One Price. In a competitive market, identical goods (a 3T MRI scan) should command identical prices. In Vermont, they do not.

body.title: The Price of Leverage: 2025 Market Rates

children.text: Economically, this is not a pricing error. It is the result of Market Power. UVMMC functions as a 'Differentiated Oligopoly.' Because they are the sole provider of essential, non-substitutable services (Trauma, Burn Unit), they leverage this monopoly power to demand exorbitant rents on substitutable services. They effectively say to the insurer: 'If you want access to our Trauma Center, you must pay $6,500 for our MRIs.'

The villain in this story is not a person; it is an incentive structure. Under Fee-For-Service, healthcare providers are paid for volume, not value. Every test, scan, and visit is a billable unit. This creates a fundamental misalignment between the hospital’s financial health and the patient’s financial health.

The Fee-For-Service model turns the patient into a 'revenue extraction unit.' To cover massive fixed costs, the hospital needs the $6,500 MRI to subsidize its other operations, creating a perverse incentive to hoard simple procedures that could be done cheaper elsewhere.

This leads to 'Physician-Induced Demand' (PID). Because of Information Asymmetry, the doctor (Agent) influences the patient (Principal). UVMMC, burdened by a 31% non-clinical administrative load, needs high throughput to survive. Thus, physicians are subtly incentivized to keep care 'in-house,' steering patients toward the $6,500 option rather than the $1,799 independent one.
III. The Demographic Trap: A Pyramid Scheme Collapse

The Wyman Report provides the grim context: Vermont is aging faster than it can pay. Healthcare financing in the US is essentially a Ponzi scheme that relies on a large base of healthy, working-age people paying premiums to subsidize the care of the elderly. By 2040, 30% of Vermonters will be over age 65, while the working-age population shrinks by 13%.

You cannot fund a 'Rolls-Royce' academic medical system on a shrinking, aging tax base using a Fee-For-Service model. As the pool of commercially insured people shrinks, the hospital must charge them even more per unit to maintain revenue. This creates a Death Spiral: premiums rise, healthy people drop coverage, the risk pool gets sicker, and premiums rise again.

The only structural fix is to kill Fee-For-Service and move to Global Budgets (The Maryland Model). Instead of negotiating the price of an MRI, the state sets a Total Revenue Cap for UVMMC (e.g., $2.5 Billion/year).

This flips the incentives entirely. Under a Global Budget, that $6,500 MRI is no longer 'profit'—it is an 'expense' against the fixed budget. UVMMC would suddenly want to partner with the $1,799 independent center to save its own resources. The war ends because the economic reason for the war—volume maximization—is removed.
